title: Can an atheist be spiritual? - Quora

response.answer_text: That really depends on what your definition of atheism is. In a conventional sense, no, because atheism is usually defined as a rejection of anything beyond the physical realm, a belief largely based on an ontological thesis called Physicalism. However, in a broad sense, perhaps it is possible. If you are a practical atheist, and you simply reject the idea of a deity due to the lack of reason or motivation express interest in theism or because you simply cannot be bothered with the idea of God or gods, you may still have a chance at being spiritual if you subscribe to some other ideas that are spiritual but not theistic. Examples: (1) You do not believe in God but you believe there is a force of good in all people that enables us to do good things or become better. That’s still a form of spirituality. (2) You reject the idea of God but you believe the Earth is one living thing and each inhabitant is a vital organ. (3) You can’t be bothered to believe in God but you feel the need to make yourself better. You become selfless and devote your life to finding ways to make life better for everyone, acknowledging that we are all of the same substance and we are, therefore, essentially one. Perhaps “atheist”, because of the conventional notion of what it’s “supposed to mean,” is a very restrictive term. “Non-theist” would be more appropriate. In fact, there are even non-theistic religions. To name some: (1) Buddhism in its original and ancient form. Gautama Buddha taught that perfection can be achieved through the middle way, purifying one’s self through meditation, service and living on Earth through the noble eight-fold path—one lifetime after another and another and another. He did not talk about God. (2) Yogic Hinduism. Patanjali, the author of the Yoga Sutras, taught that Samadhi or “concentrative union” is the ultimate goal and it does not consider God’s existence as either essential or necessary to achieving this. (3) Jainism. It holds that the universe and the matter and souls within it are eternal and uncreated, and there is no omnipotent creator God. (4) Non-theistic Quakerism. While not subscribing to the notions of God, non-theistic Quakers value the community in the Society of Friends and appreciate the good work they do and the peacefulness, calmness and serenity of the silence in Meeting for Worship.

That depends upon the definition of the word “Atheism” that one adheres to. If one attaches atheism directly to religion, takes the literal meaning that an atheist is a person without religion (or anti-religion) — then it is indeed possible for an atheist to be a spiritualist. Because this person does not need proof or evidence to make life decisions, apparently, just a gut feeling would suffice. But if the more common translation of the word is used, which means that an atheist is basically a rational, critical, sceptical thinker who does not take anything for granted but must have at least some proof to let something guide his/her mind and morals — then we would not see this person take up spirituality as a mantra. Simply because s/he has just as much proof of having a soul as much as lord Visnu’s footprints. Spiritualism can be called a non-organized religion, a new idea that hasn’t yet gotten to build its mint. People started with worshipping many gods, we call that polytheism now. Pagans and nature worshippers of old and many more obscure forgotten parties are examples of this. Then monotheism prevailed in the form of worshipping one true god; although we have a couple of them in the major league. Well, now comes the “zerotheism” - in the age of digital isolation, worship yourself! Self-growth! Forget the world, you are the important thing! Help people only because it gives you spiritual currency in the bank! We call that ‘karma’ now. Note that it works upon the same basic principle of religion — make people afraid of something. In this case, backlash of karma. While an atheist makes moral decisions unafraid of anything, unless be it a very real gun pressing on his/her temple. This is why it would be hypocritical for a modern atheist to believe in soul but not believe in God. The simple reasoning goes that if God exists, Allah has to exist as well. And your soul. And the flying spaghetti monster. And oh yes ghosts and somebody illiterate can cure your bronchial arythmia by just looking at you. And my dad was queen Isabella. You can’t not believe in one thing if you believe in another, because all of them have the same proof — a lot of shouting. The street is not one-way, though. The problem with Atheism is that it is highly vulnerable to being contaminated by simple rebellion. This is why we see the garden-variety homegrown atheists here and there, angry and spewing disrespect for systems that has been guiding humanity for thousands of years. They are, literally, all talk. And they are also one of the reason Atheism gathers so much negative feedback. Simply put, it is like this. You either believe, or you know. There is no middle ground. Atheism is not about what you believe in or not. Atheism is not about whether god exists or soul exists or not. It is a toggle-switch in your head: “Logic: ON/OFF.” Or proof, or rationality — pick your brand of word. Means all the same — do you ‘believe’ it or do you ‘know’ it? Atheism is transcendence. All of those were many wines of different brands — atheism is quitting. And the rehab if needed.  Atheism is going into the light.

First, let me get the definitions out of the way. Atheism is nothing more than a rejection of the belief that god (or gods) exists. It is not even a position against supernaturalism. It is not even a pro-science position. It is only a “I do not believe gods exist” position. As such, there may exist atheists who believe in ghosts, pseudo-scientific theories, mystic healing, and magic. There may also be atheists who are racist, ethnocentric, and politically conservative. Atheism does not stop people from being any of these things. It’s only about not believing that gods exist. Now to define spirituality. No two people will define spirituality the same way. It can indeed be literally about spirits (ghosts and suchlike), or it can be about something more beyond words. When asked if they are spiritual, people nod in the affirmative. But when asked what they mean by it, they dissolve into ambiguity. I have heard people say, without using the word “god”, that their spirituality is about “a higher power” or “something above us all” or “just a feeling”. Spirituality remains undefined, and because of that, it remains prevalent. Religion is easy to reject in modern times. But a lot of religious baggage sneaks into rational minds disguised as spirituality. Depending on how we define spirituality therefore, there may be atheists who can be defined as spiritual. But they probably won’t define it as having anything to do with a higher power that exerts any influence on their lives. Their definitions will be more… how shall I put it… esoteric. There is a worldview known as Religious Naturalism that Carl Sagan might be described as having subscribed to[1]. It finds in the scientific understanding of the world something that resembles religious feeling. Some people feel it in shrines, temples, mosques, and churches. Some feel it when watching Cosmos. I am an atheist. And I have a definition of spirituality also. To me, spirituality means the search for meaning. So the simple act of opening the dictionary to look up a word is spiritual to me. To understand something is, to me, the highest possible calling of a human being. All religion and all spirituality stems from the human need to understand. In ages past, we explained the universe using stories. These stories were the best we could do, and to some extent, they hold meaning even today. They tell us about ways of being and methods of conduct. What has changed is that we have come to a greater understanding of not only the universe, but also the impulse that causes us to look for meaning. The human condition is defined, not by supernatural influences, but by our species’ imaginative outlook. This is, at least to this atheist, kind of spiritual. Footnotes[1] Carl Sagan

I would say so! I’ve considered my world/faith view, spiritual for several years now, with no particular pinning to a specific religion or belief system. It’s something I’ve long contemplated, an enjoy doing so! I certainly couldn’t call myself an atheist in that very wide sense, of course. …but, what does it meant to be spiritual? Essentially, for me my spiritual life has meant living with constant awareness or consciousness over all aspects of myself; my mind, my emotions, my surrounds, relations, and so on. For me, spirituality could readily be changed with the term metaphysics. Standard physicals, as we know, investigates forces and physical impacts on reality. Metaphysics looks at those which aren’t so tangible and measurable to us; love for example. Thus, by this definition, I could say that spiritualism is about interconnection; firstly between the aspects of oneself, then by extension of life, and the world around us. You could argue that an atheist, being someone who holds no active faith, may not put any focus into the these sorts of considerations over life; but, in keeping with our inter-connective virtue/nature, on this, we can understand that although a person may categorically identify as an atheist, life is not so categorical; rather categories - ‘atheism’ being one - are simply modes of group aspects of life. Therefore, two individuals could call themselves atheists, but have very different approaches to life - one even more ‘aware’ than the other, just as two religious individuals may have very differing ideas and life approaches. In a concluded answer to your questions, I’d say yes, an atheist could be spiritual; perhaps not ideologically (but this is a simple matter of words; semantics, and what we call things) but in principle, I can’t see a great deal which would completely disqualify a person with atheistic views practically living a spiritual life!

So many excellent answers here already; it’s strange that reading through these inspired me to add something, but that’s the feeling I have right now. The notion that atheists share any characteristics other than their atheism is disconcerting for me. The simplest, only thing that atheists share is that they do not believe in a god or gods. That’s it. Atheists don’t espouse doctrine, they don’t (in most cases), even care if others believe in their gods. Certainly, there are some that attempt to elevate their position as atheists into some sort of authority about religion not being valid without the existence of god or gods but for the most part, it’s a personal observation of the fact that there is no god, are no gods. I don’t believe in a god or gods. I do, however, have a great deal of faith. Faith in myself, in others. Faith, for me, is not defined by the fact there is no god or gods. My faith is that we can be good, moral people that work together toward good ends. Not in every case, and not in every situation, but in general I can and have relied upon the good nature of people in any place I’ve traveled. I do not do so in a naive way, but my faith has carried me when I needed to find meaning in a situation. Religion is nothing more than an attempt to co-opt or annex the need for meaning that each of us has within. While many religious texts and the prophets of these same religions say that you don’t need to be in a structure or have any organization at all to access ‘god’ through prayer and devotion, the religious structures themselves demand attendance, tithe, and other things that go counter to their own doctrine. Their prophets speak words of peace, yet their doctrine preaches nothing but hate and violence. I read several answers that atheists cannot believe in souls if they don’t believe in a god or gods, but the two things are entirely unrelated. Whether or not I have a soul is irrelevant to me; if there is something after this physical life, some part of me that will exist beyond my time as a conscious being here and now, then I will learn this when I can experience it. Not before, not because of convenient excuses about how in each life here we forget our knowledge of another life outside of here. Only when this existence ends will I know, and that’s easy for me to accept. This links me to the point of this question, which is whether or not I can be spiritual as an atheist. The shortest answer is: “Yes, I can be spiritual and an atheist.” The longer answer is always more useful. Spirituality, to me, is an openness to the world; an acceptance of the myriad possibility of our world. One of these myriad possibilities is that there is more than one world, that somehow there are things beyond my experience or that I might experience if I push myself toward them. But that is not all that spirituality is; it’s an openness to the sublime. I possess the ability to be openly affected by the things of beauty as well as the things of horror that we encounter in life. The word ‘spirituality’ is ill-defined for a good set of answers to a question like this. I defined mine above, your mileage may vary (and I expect it will) because each of us is on a separate journey. Inherent within us all, though, is seeking meaning in the world. We can find it within us, within the world around us, within a dogmatic structure that tells us what that meaning is, or any combination within or without these things I’ve listed. edited: for clarity and typos.

No, atheists cannot be spiritual. IMO, spirituality is a way of thinking about Nature in terms of human or human-like agents. That is, trying to understand how Nature works, not in terms of universal, immutable rules (e.g. Laws of Physics) but in terms of mental states similar to our own (e.g. intentions, desires, goals…). Another way to bring out the difference between these two ways of thinking is the following - a Materialist believes that matter is fundamental while mind is emergent from it while a Spiritualist believes exactly the opposite. That is why there is a fundamental disconnect between these two camps on the question of origins - there is no mind (or external agent/creator/designer) that figures in the theories of Big Bang, Evolution, Abiogenesis etc. How did humans come to believe that the universe is somehow controlled by a human-like agent and that it has a purpose which somehow revolves around humans? It happened because the human species evolved as the most social among mammals. Consequently, our minds are optimized for social cognition and not mechanical cognition. By default we tend to attribute mental states to understand anything, whether people or animals, machines, rocks, rivers or trees rather than trying to analyze their behaviour in terms of mechanistic rules. So Atheism should logically extend to having a materialistic understanding of the universe as opposed to spiritual. And that is why there is a certain contradiction in calling yourself a spiritual Atheist.

So when I say I'm not spiritual, they think I'm saying I'm incapable of love, can't enjoy a sunset, feel no awe when I stand on a cliff overlooking the ocean, realizing how small I am, and am completely unaffected by music like this:  Nothing could be further from the truth, but I find "spiritual" an odd and confusing word to label the concept of "having deep feelings." However, if I started believing in any or all of those things tomorrow, I would still be an atheist. I will remain an atheist, as long as I don't believe in God or gods.

Yes, as long as you keep faith out of it. I recommend the book Waking Up by Sam Harris about this very subject. In his usage of the term, the best usage, IMO, “spirituality” refers to some recognition that life is hard, and that the mind tends to race and wander in a way that makes life even harder. At some point one must figure out how to relax, as it were, and to realize that the best life is not simply the gratification of wants nor the repetitions of pleasure. Harris has quite a background in Buddhist traditions — I don’t know what all — he gets sort of technical and in-depth about that, but I tend to gloss over that. His biggest point is that you don’t need any sectarian nor denominational loyalties nor for that matter faith at all to take this journey. If you read just a little of the book, I recommend the first chapter and the beautiful Conclusion at the very end. He writes towards the end: Spirituality remains the great hole in secularism, humanism, rationalism, atheism, and all other defensive postures that reasonable men and women strike in the presence of unreasonable faith. People on both sides of this divide imagine that visionary experience has no place within the context of a science -- apart from the corridors of a mental hospital. Until we can talk about spirituality in rational terms -- acknowledging the validity of self-transcendence -- our world will remain shattered by dogmatism. This book has been my attempt to being such a conversation.

response.answer_text: Computer people speak of hardware and software. By “hardware,” they mean the physical computer and its peripherals (external disk drive, printer, etc.). By“software,” they mean the values and applications stored in its memory. The software commands the computer to read values from its memory, store them in other locations, and manipulate them in various ways. Each command can be as simple as “Add A to B,” but when millions of commands are executed at high speed, the result can be Watson, the computer program that understood and answered the questions on Jeopardy so skillfully that it defeated an all-time champion. Watson is not itself a material object. That’s why we call it software rather than hardware. But no one would describe it as metaphysical or supernatural or paranormal; it is clearly a manifestation of the material world. Our world is filled with software that is a function of the material world just as a computer's applications are a function of its hardware. We call this software plays, paintings,music, love affairs, heroic acts, and the beauty of nature. As the poet and novelist Nikos Kazantzakis wrote, "What a strange machine man is! You fill him with bread, wine, fish,and radishes, and out come sighs, laughter, and dreams." When we visit Notre Dame cathedral and look up at its arches and its great rose windows, we feel awe. The sponsors of the cathedral intended that awe to suggest religious feelings, but its architects learned how to inspire the awe from nature: “Whether one is watching a thrilling thunderstorm or looking up at a mighty tree, the experience of nature is one of awe. One cannot help but marvel at the intricate design of a single leaf, or the roar of a great waterfall.”[1] Even the sensation of spirituality is generated by a physical part of our brain: "Brain surgeons have discovered that stimulating the temporal lobe during surgery in alert patients can elicit intensely spiritual emotions even in self-described atheists.”[2]  [1]http://www.familyfriendpoems.com/poems/ture/#ixzz3fimu556 [2]Daniel Lieberman, The Story of the HumanBody: Evolution, Health, and Disease.
